title: What kind of a tech business can be started by offering services? - Quora

response.answer_text: The grandaddy of “service” business models in tech are staffing and consulting. There are so many “consulting” and “contracting” agencies it’s not even funny. You can do it as an individual, or as a group, and companies can grow from this. In other words, you can sell knowledge and know how. Staffing is all about finding the right people to do work. Consulting is providing guidance about how a project should be be done. Consulting tends to be far more about planning and establishing predictability while staffing is getting it done. There are also content services, such as educational platforms. You can sell tutorials, lessons, programs, etc. These are still human-powered services. Bottom line: you can start by selling knowledge. — It is very common for people to start out as a freelancer, looking to make the move into “consulting” and eventually into a “product” business. This fails most of the time because people underestimate the sheer volume of effort required to build a consulting practice (lots of networking, marketing, sales, etc). Products tend to be pushed to the side, because they follow a different business model which is equally demanding. So, consider your future very carefully if you’re considering a “service first” approach to launching a business. It’s a good way to make a living, but it’s not the best “gateway” to another line of business. More successful tech companies start by building a product, either bootstrapping or raising funds. Services are added later, after the market has expanded. This is how open source systems like Red Hat got off the ground. Product first, expanding into services.

Typically, you should start something in an area in which you have heavy duty domain knowledge. We’ve shared many Bootstrapping Using Services case studies on the One Million by One Million blog, as well as in the book on that topic. Here’s one that is particularly interesting because of the absolutely awesome business model that Nilay and his team have implemented. It’s in the domain of Accounts Payable negotiation and related costs savings. Read: Bootstrapping Using Services to an Awesome Business Model: Inspyrus CEO Nilay Banker | Sramana Mitra If you read the case study, you’ll see how the entrepreneurs spend considerable time developing deep customer relationships and trust, as well as learn the problem domain intimately. Customer intimacy in a particular domain is the key to successful bootstrapping using services.
